Description:
Bangladesh is often called the Land of Rivers. With a total of 1,415 rivers flowing across the country, these waterways play a crucial role in shaping its economy and daily life.

Rivers provide numerous benefits to the people of Bangladesh, including:

  • Making the land fertile for agriculture
  • Providing a major source of food and livelihoods
  • Supporting transportation and communication
  • Enabling trade and economic activities

However, these same rivers can also become a source of danger. When they overflow, they can trigger devastating floods, invading people’s homes, land, and resources.

The geographic location and the flat, low-lying topography make Bangladesh one of the most flood-prone countries in the world.

Floods have been a recurring threat for decades:

  • Between 1971 and 2014, Bangladesh experienced 78 major flood events.
  • These floods caused the deaths of approximately 42,000 people.
  • The estimated economic loss during this period amounts to USD 12.2 billion.

Today, more than 70 million people in Bangladesh live in flood-prone areas, placing their lives, livelihoods, and properties at constant risk.

Floods disproportionately affect children, older adults, and other socially disadvantaged groups, many of whom require additional support and protection during disaster events.

Key inequities in flood impacts include:

  • The lowest income households lose nearly all of their income during disaster periods, while the highest income households experience only a small reduction.
  • Infants born to mothers living in flood-prone areas suffer markedly higher mortality rates in their first year compared to those born in safer regions.

These patterns reveal that the impacts of flooding in Bangladesh are highly unequal across social and demographic groups. This underscores the critical need for targeted, equity-focused disaster risk reduction and climate adaptation policies to protect the most vulnerable populations.

Objectives of the Study

  1. Visualize the flood-affected areas in Bangladesh in 2021 using the existing surface water map and flood risk map.
  2. Determine the Social Vulnerability Index (SVI) at the district level using relevant factors from the Census 2022.
  3. Merge the SVI with 2021 flood exposure and flood risk, and visualize their intersection to identify areas with both high social vulnerability and high flood exposure or risk.

Chapter: How the Social Vulnerability varies across Districts in Bangladesh?
Description:
The map shows that social vulnerability varies significantly across Bangladesh. Districts in the northern, central, and southeastern regions display higher Social Vulnerability Index (SVI) values, represented by darker red areas. These locations typically have limited socioeconomic resources, higher population pressures, and reduced access to essential services.

In contrast, districts shaded in lighter colors indicate lower vulnerability, reflecting better social and economic conditions. The clear spatial variation shown in the map underscores the importance of region-specific strategies to reduce social vulnerability and strengthen resilience.
